text:
In this video, you’ll see how to build shell
 scripts with Amazon CodeWhisperer.

With this AI-powered tool, you can use 
code suggestions to create shell scripts
that automate tasks and secure your applications.

We’ll begin in Visual Studio Code (VS Code), 
where CodeWhisperer has already been enabled.
Let’s save our shell script in a “samples” folder.
Next, we’ll build our shell script.

Let’s start writing a comment that tells 
CodeWhisperer to add a bin/bash header.
CodeWhisperer completes the comment for us.

To accept it, we’ll press the 
Tab key on our keyboard.

Next, we’ll write a comment that tells 
CodeWhisperer to list Amazon EC2

instances in the current region 
with the tag “Environment=Dev."
We’ll accept CodeWhisperer’s suggested script.

The script will filter for instances with 
the tag key and value we specified,

and query for instance details, 
including the instance ID and type.
The script will then output the results as a table.

Now let’s open a terminal 
window and test our script.

Our script works as expected and 
outputs the instance details in a table.
Let’s return to our script in VS Code.

Now let’s tell CodeWhisperer to stop instances in 
the current region with the tag “Environment=Dev.”

CodeWhisperer recommends 
using aws ec2 stop-instances.
We’ll accept the suggestion.

The script will filter for instances with
 the tag key and value we specified,

query for the instance ID, 
and output the results as text.
Let's test our script again.
The script first returns the instance details.

The script then stops the instance and 
shows its current and previous state.

Now let's go back to Visual Studio 
code and modify our script further.

For now, let’s turn the line we 
just added into a comment.

We’ll tell CodeWhisperer to start instances in 
the current region with the tag “Environment=Dev.”
We’ll accept CodeWhisperer’s suggestion.
The line is currently a comment like the stop line.
Let’s uncomment the line and test the script.
Again, the script first returns the instance details.

This time, the script starts the 
instances instead of stopping them.
Now let’s open a new shell script.

In this file, we’ll install our 
Web server components.
First, let’s add a bin/bash header.

Since we’re installing the components 
to an Amazon EC2 Linux instance,

we’ll tell CodeWhisperer to update the 
YUM package management utility.
We’ll accept CodeWhisperer’s suggestion.
Next, we’ll install the web server components.

We’ll modify CodeWhisperer’s 
suggested code to remove php-mysql.

CodeWhisperer suggested starting the 
web server, but we won’t do this quite yet.

First, we’ll use CodeWhisperer to 
create a hello world webpage file.
Now we’re ready to start the webserver.
Let’s test the script.
First, we’ll create a file in the /tmp directory.

Next, we’ll paste the content generated with
Amazon CodeWhisperer and save the file.
Let’s run the file.

The script will now update YUM, install the 
httpd and php components, create the hello
world webpage file, and start the web server.

The script finished executing, 
and the web server is running.
Now let’s run a curl command to test our webpage.

The “hello world” message is returned, 
indicating everything is working as expected.

We can also use CodeWhisperer to install 
Docker in an Amazon EC2 Linux instance.

Instead of searching outside sources to install 
Docker from, we can enter a simple comment.

We’ll accept CodeWhisperer’s suggestions to update 
YUM, install Docker, and start the Docker service.

Next, we’ll request to run a 
container with an NGINX image.
Next, we’ll check if the container is running.

CodeWhisperer recommends 
checking the container logs.

This command will display the 
logs for the specified container.

You’ve just seen how to build shell 
scripts with Amazon CodeWhisperer.

You can learn more about this topic in 
the description and links for this video.
Thanks for watching. Now it’s your turn to try.
